210.speaker: Gale
210.text: Nothing a bit of magic can't solve.

168.speaker: Gale
168.text: Why don't we take a little break? Allow ourselves a few moments of rest. Gives me a chance to talk to you about something, well, rather important.

159.speaker: Player
159.text: 'Rather important' no less? All right, go ahead.

118.speaker: Player
118.text: I assume this might have something to do with that mysterious protocol of yours?

284.speaker: Gale
284.text: Putting two and two together I see.

89.speaker: Player
89.text: Whatever it is, do make it brief.

171.speaker: Gale
171.text: We've been on the road together for a while now, haven't we? Survived some perils, overcame some obstacles.

144.speaker: Gale
144.text: Ever since you were kind enough to free me from that stone, I've seen you demonstrate remarkable guile and courage.

184.speaker: Gale
184.text: The way you defused the tension between Zevlor and Aradin.

166.speaker: Gale
166.text: The way we defused the tension between Zevlor and Aradin.

345.speaker: Gale
345.text: The way you stood in front of a crossbow to prevent a murder.

87.speaker: Gale
87.text: The way one of our own stood in front of a crossbow to prevent a murder.

236.speaker: Gale
236.text: The way you got Kagha to release the girl.

84.speaker: Gale
84.text: The way we got Kagha to release the girl.

188.speaker: Gale
188.text: The way you handled Nettie when she poisoned you.

243.speaker: Gale
243.text: The way you got that boy out of a harpy's clutches.

29.speaker: Gale
29.text: The way you followed the protocol and brought me back to life.

124.speaker: Gale
124.text: These deeds attest to a strong and noble character. They attest to prime leadership qualities as well.

305.speaker: Gale
305.text: In short: I've grown to trust you.

17.speaker: Gale
17.text: The reason I make a point of saying this is that I've grown confident enough to tell you something I've yet to tell another living soul. Except for my cat.

234.speaker: Gale
234.text: You see, I have this... condition. Very different from the parasite we share, but just as deadly.

186.speaker: Gale
186.text: The specifics are rather personal, but suffice it to say that it is a malady I have learned to live with - though not without some effort.

274.speaker: Player
274.text: You also feel disgusted by how life, miserable as it is, insists of persisting in this most wretched world?

173.speaker: Gale
173.text: No, no - nothing like that. Though if I fail to treat it then the consequences would not be contained to me alone.

81.speaker: Gale
81.text: No, it cannot be cured. And I assure you I've left no page unturned in reaching that conclusion.

132.speaker: Gale
132.text: I can keep this condition under control, as indeed I've done for a significant amount of time, but that was under different circumstances altogether. Home, in Waterdeep.

176.speaker: Gale
176.text: What it comes down to is this: every so often I need to get my hands on a powerful magical item and absorb the Weave inside.

291.speaker: Player
291.text: Your illness causes you to consume raw magic? I'm going to need the details...

177.speaker: Gale
177.text: I can say no more on the matter - not now anyway.

308.speaker: Gale
308.text: Just trust me when I say it's all of vital importance.

8.speaker: Player
8.text: What kind of items are we talking about exactly?

299.speaker: Gale
299.text: Staffs, tomes, cowls - the form doesn't matter, so long as it's brimming with Weave.

194.speaker: Gale
194.text: Trust me when I say - the loss of the occasional wizard's staff or tome of enchantment is a bargain given the cost of allowing me to deteriorate.

304.speaker: Player
304.text: What happens if you don't consume these artefacts?

94.speaker: Gale
94.text: I'll spare you the finer details, but it begins with a simple biological deterioration. Muscle spasms, disorientation, a slight ringing in the ears. And if left for too long...

219.speaker: Gale
219.context: NodeContext: Matter of fact. With a levity you don’t expect to hear the word spoken.

73.speaker: Gale
73.text: It's been days since I last consumed an artefact - since before we were abducted. It is time.

222.speaker: Gale
222.text: And by that I mean it's imperative that I find and consume strands of Weave at the earliest possible juncture.

351.speaker: Gale
351.text: It's been days since I last consumed an artefact - since before we were abducted. It's only a matter of time before my craving returns.

178.speaker: Gale
178.text: That is why I turn to you. I need you to help me find magic items to consume. It is vital. Dare I say it, critical.

134.speaker: Player
134.text: Where do you suggest we find the artefacts you need?

20.speaker: Gale
20.text: As luck would have it, Faerûn is full of them, though I do feel obliged to point out that items of power tend to be in the hands of the powerful.

120.speaker: Gale
120.text: There will be danger involved - or great cost.

241.speaker: Player
241.text: I expected as much. Don't worry - I'm happy to help.

327.speaker: Gale
327.text: Splendid. A bit of boldness will serve us well.

289.speaker: Player
289.text: Why exactly would I risk either of those things for a wizard I barely know?

258.speaker: Gale
258.text: Valid question. If not out of the simple goodness of your heart, then perhaps your own self-interest might be sufficient motivation.

23.speaker: Gale
23.text: Having a wizard like me around is quite the boon when facing the perils that stalk these lands. It will be far harder for me to assist you if I can barely stand upright.

286.speaker: Player
286.text: And at the end of all that I lose a valuable artefact? No thanks.

5.speaker: Gale
5.text: I know that what I ask may seem unreasonable, but I promise I only make such a request because it is so incredibly important.

150.speaker: Gale
150.text: Please - trust me. Your help could be the difference between life and death.

45.speaker: Player
45.text: Very well, I'll do my best to get you what you need.

353.speaker: Gale
353.text: As luck would have it, you're already primed to give me exactly what I need...

350.speaker: Gale
350.text: Thank you. I see my trust in you was not misplaced!

14.speaker: Gale
14.text: I'm sure we won't have to look very far to find what I need: Faerûn overflows with magic-infused treasure.

19.speaker: Gale
19.text: As do our packs, as a matter of fact. We've such an item already in our possession, primed for the moment the need arises.

57.speaker: Gale
57.text: I know the allure magic artefacts hold. I understand their value and their power. All this to say: I understand the sacrifice I ask of you.

22.speaker: Gale
22.text: But if I may be so bold: it's for a very good cause indeed.

224.speaker: Gale
224.text: I hope I can count on you.

158.speaker: Gale
158.text: Oh, and as far as that tadpole trickery goes, I really do trust you'll not be so untoward again.

121.speaker: Player
121.text: I have powerful magic in my possession already. Take what you need.

335.speaker: Gale
335.text: You're slightly ahead of me there. As yet, my condition is stable. I've no need to consume anything.

307.speaker: Gale
307.text: When the time comes, I will not hesitate to call on you or the belongings you were generous enough to offer.

90.speaker: Player
90.text: My help was already the difference between life and death where you're concerned. You owe me an explanation.

271.speaker: Gale
271.text: I'm afraid it doesn't quite work like that - though of course I'm immensely grateful for any assistance you provide in times of mortal peril. But I must ask more trust of you still.

251.speaker: Player
251.text: No. If you aren't willing to tell me the truth, I'm not helping you.

225.speaker: Gale
225.text: I understand that I'm asking for a lot, but I can't tell you everything. Not yet anyway.

294.speaker: Player
294.text: You aren't going to drop this, are you?

187.speaker: Player
187.text: Fine. I'll help you. If only to shut you up.

227.speaker: Player
227.text: Neither am I. We'll have to see who gives up first.

50.speaker: Gale
50.text: I don't know how else I can explain the imperative nature of this issue. You can't simply dismiss it.
50.context: NodeContext: Getting annoyed/ hint of disbelief that you're refusing him so adamantly

322.speaker: Gale
322.text: Very well. You're clearly in no mood to be receptive to my request at present.

292.speaker: Gale
292.text: Take whatever time you need to consider. I hope, when the reality of my condition sets in, you may yet be convinced to change your mind.

109.speaker: Player
109.text: No, I won't. And that's final.

295.speaker: Player
295.text: Use your tadpole. Seek the danger at the heart of Gale's request.

162.speaker: Narrator
162.text: *You become one with Gale's mind and you can feel something sinister oppressing you.*

255.speaker: Narrator
255.text: *It's... inside of you, a mighty darkness radiating from your chest.*

52.speaker: Narrator
52.text: *You could try to push further, but your hold over Gale feels brittle. It won't be easy delving deeper without him noticing.*

163.speaker: Narrator
163.text: *You see through Gale's eyes, staring down the corridors of a dread memory. A book, bound, then suddenly opened.*

179.speaker: Narrator
179.text: *Inside there are no pages, only a swirling mass of blackest Weave that pounces.*

230.speaker: Narrator
230.text: *It's teeth, it's claws, it's unstoppable as it digs through and becomes part of you. And gods, is it ever-hungry...*

333.speaker: Gale
333.text: Keeping me in suspense, are you? Come on, tell me, do we have an agreement or not?

354.speaker: Player
354.text: No. I want nothing to do with the matter.

149.speaker: Player
149.text: What you saw makes you hesitate.

106.speaker: Gale
106.text: It's a simple question, isn't it? What gives you pause?

40.speaker: Player
40.text: Keep your reservations to yourself. Offer Gale your help.

226.speaker: Player
226.text: Risk telling Gale what the tadpole showed you.

330.speaker: Gale
330.text: You used that thing against me? And you saw! After I told you...

317.speaker: Gale
317.text: You had no right! None at all! I've a good mind to turn around and depart this little company of ours immediately.

69.speaker: Gale
69.text: I'd rather be alone than spend another moment in the presence of someone inclined to such unjustified invasions of privacy.

185.speaker: Player
185.text: Be reasonable, Gale. Your condition is unstable, possibly dangerous - I needed to know.

156.speaker: Gale
156.text: The need remains debatable, but I recognise your responsibility.
156.context: NodeContext: Still angry, but the player convinced him to stay, so slightly softer.

133.speaker: Gale
133.text: Perhaps my reaction was a tad volatile, the irony of which is not lost on me. Though it needs remain so on you, for the time being.

37.speaker: Gale
37.text: I hope that the glimpse you caught on my condition convinced you of the urgency in treating it. Can I count on you to give me the artefacts I need?

201.speaker: Player
201.text: Of course. I'm happy to help you.

64.speaker: Player
64.text: You lied to me, Gale. I need time to think about this.

153.speaker: Gale
153.text: That is a lie and you know it.

341.speaker: Gale
341.text: This is where we part ways.

223.speaker: Player
223.text: You're in mortal danger twice over. To leave would be foolish, and you're no fool.

191.speaker: Gale
191.text: I have to admit you're right about that.
191.context: NodeContext: Still angry, but the player convinced him to stay, so slightly softer.

207.speaker: Gale
207.text: I am a fool. A fool to have trusted you.

231.speaker: Player
231.text: Good, because whatever that thing is inside you, I want it nowhere near me.

135.speaker: Gale
135.text: What are you... You're using the tadpole against me?

359.speaker: Player
359.text: Very well. I'll help you manage this condition of yours.

256.speaker: Gale
256.text: I'm afraid that's not going to work on me. Look, I appreciate your curiosity, but don't pursue this path.

56.speaker: Gale
56.text: Let us agree on actions first and explanations later. Yes?

331.speaker: Player
331.text: Very well. I'll help you, though I expect an explanation eventually.

129.speaker: Player
129.text: Sorry - that's not going work for me. I need an explanation.

100.speaker: Player
100.text: I'm not helping with this, Gale. Now let the matter rest.

128.speaker: Player
128.text: Honestly, that sounds terrible. I see no upside to this for me.

123.speaker: Gale
123.text: Then I suggest you look closer.

339.speaker: Gale
339.text: We've already done the finding. In fact you have one in your possession.

96.speaker: Gale
96.text: You know for yourself how hard won such an item was, and it will be no easier when even more are required to assuage my hunger.

319.speaker: Player
319.text: I fail to see why you need me to help you with this. You've done fine without me so far.

76.speaker: Gale
76.text: A fair point - however, until recently I was able to rely on a supply of artefacts stored in my tower in Waterdeep. A  supply that has now run dry.

360.speaker: Gale
360.text: The reality of the matter is that a lone wizard with a chronic impairment such as my own is not in the most ideal of situations with regards to self-defence.

296.speaker: Gale
296.text: The manner of artefacts I need are not often found waiting patiently on a shop-keep's shelf. One usually has to lift them delicately from trap-filled tombs or prise them from the hands of violent ne'erdowells.

60.speaker: Gale
60.text: You have my thanks. And fear not - your implicit trust is well placed, and will be rewarded with any and all means at my disposal.
60.context: NodeContext: Surprised it was that easy, but happy to go with it

312.speaker: Player
312.text: Sounds like no 'condition' I've ever heard of. I'd say you're just fishing for loot.

265.speaker: Gale
265.text: Please. I've better things to do with my time than hoodwink gullible adventurers out of their trinkets.
265.context: NodeContext: Scoffing a bit - he'd never stoop to such juvenile behaviour

309.speaker: Player
309.text: Are you telling me you're addicted to magic?

203.speaker: Gale
203.text: No - no, it's nothing like that. Magic isn't a narcotic to me, it's quite literally a life-saver.

325.speaker: Gale
325.text: I would not burden anyone other than myself with this were the stakes not so high, and the means of obtaining such artefacts challenging for a humble wizard to face alone.

55.speaker: Player
55.text: So you've been lying to me this whole time. Wonderful.

122.speaker: Gale
122.text: I am what I am - I never lied to you, I've merely been economical with the truth.

67.speaker: Player
67.text: I could pray on your behalf. My god may offer some guidance on how you might be cured.

169.speaker: Gale
169.text: Thank you for the offer, but the treatment for my condition is very specific.

211.speaker: Player
211.text: Enough with the flattery. Where is this going?

269.speaker: Gale
269.text: I was being quite sincere, I assure you.

242.speaker: Player
242.text: Can't say the feeling's exactly mutual.

262.speaker: Gale
262.text: Be that as it may, my trust is yours.

336.speaker: Gale
336.text: The way we got that boy out of a harpy's clutches.

357.speaker: Gale
357.text: The way we handled Nettie when she wanted to poison us.

343.speaker: Player
343.text: No rest for the likes of us, Gale.

126.speaker: Gale
126.text: What, no rest for the dashing? Pish posh.

77.speaker: Gale
77.text: Spare me a moment, if you please. I've something important to discuss with you.
77.context: InternalNodeContext: Night 4 - Night 3 hasn't happened, Approval isn't high enough for it, and Gale is asking for magic items.NodeContext:  A bit more sombre and serious here. In this intro he feels compelled to speak out of necessity, but he doesn’t really want to.

235.speaker: Gale
235.text: That said, necessity compels me to set aside my reservations. I have no choice but to speak.
235.context: NodeContext:  A bit more sombre and serious here. In this intro he feels compelled to speak out of necessity, but he doesn’t really want to.

347.speaker: Gale
347.text: We've been travelling together for a while now and I think it's safe to say we don't always see eye to eye.
347.context: NodeContext:  A bit more sombre and serious here. In this intro he feels compelled to speak out of necessity, but he doesn’t really want to.

272.speaker: Gale
272.text: We've been travelling together for a while now and it's just about time that I shared something with you.

24.speaker: Gale
24.text: It's a rather personal matter that I'd have preferred to keep quiet, but needs must when the devil drives. I have no choice but to speak.

143.speaker: Gale
143.text: Tiring business, isn't it? All this travelling and adventuring.
143.context: InternalNodeContext: Night 4 - Night 3 hasn't happened, Approval isn't high enough for it, and Gale is asking for magic items.NodeContext:  A bit more sombre and serious here. In this intro he feels compelled to speak out of necessity, but he doesn’t really want to.

145.speaker: Gale
145.text: So, all it took to get Mystra's attention was to learn how to reforge an artefact that once destroyed her.

174.speaker: Gale
174.text: Obvious, when you stop to think about it.

240.speaker: Player
240.text: What do you think she wants to say?

250.speaker: Gale
250.text: Well, I doubt it's an apology for asking me to die on her behalf.

314.speaker: Gale
314.text: Whatever it is, if it's important enough to send Elminster, we can be damned sure she's serious.

281.speaker: Player
281.text: She's scared of you. You're one step closer to being able to challenge her.

38.speaker: Gale
38.text: Not scared. Not yet. But she's shaken, if she feels the need to intervene directly.

111.speaker: Gale
111.text: This is a conversation that's long overdue on both sides. I owe it to her to hear her out, come what may afterwards.

71.speaker: Player
71.text: I agree. It's time we headed for the Stormshore Tabernacle.

53.speaker: Player
53.text: Why bother? It's obvious she's just annoyed you read the book.

148.speaker: Gale
148.text: Mystra's many things, but she's no censor. Her job is not to judge those who use the Weave, but to ensure it is protected.

337.speaker: Gale
337.text: Whatever she has to say, I want to hear it. Only then will we know the truth of what lies ahead.

221.speaker: Gale
221.text: Very well, but it does not serve us to tarry when a summons from the heavens is waiting.

18.speaker: Gale
18.text: Let's not get too ahead of ourselves. For now, I'm just a regular wizard holding the blueprint for greatness.

306.speaker: Gale
306.text: Mystra knows I've read Karsus' designs, I'm certain of that. And it clearly has her shaken.

216.speaker: Player
216.text: How could she possibly know we read a book? Hasn't she got more important things to worry about?

30.speaker: Gale
30.text: The Weave is a highly sensitive magical network threaded through all life on this plane. Any shift in magical energy, no matter how small, is akin to a beacon, alerting Mystra to its cause.

193.speaker: Gale
193.text: Opening a book like the Annals of Karsus was akin to us shooting a firework spelling 'look at us, Mystra' directly into the skies of Elysium. She knows.

318.speaker: Player
318.text: Are you sure you want to go to her? She might want to punish you.

261.speaker: Gale
261.text: I think Elminster's last message was the one carrying the punishment. Having respectfully declined it, I think she's willing to negotiate.

172.speaker: Gale
172.text: I was hoping to speak to you, as a matter of fact. About the night you were kind enough to keep this melancholy wizard company...

139.speaker: Gale
139.text: I suppose one might say I'm rather adrift, to be honest.

313.speaker: Gale
313.text: Since our conversation, I'd resigned myself to my fate. Each day bore the possibility of being my last, and I accepted it.

15.speaker: Gale
15.text: I'm only standing here now because I failed, to put it in rather blunt terms. Mystra is unlikely to let me try again. Yet, even in spite of that - I'm glad to have more time with you.

32.speaker: Gale
32.text: Since you still have me, was there anything else on your mind?
32.context: NodeContext: 'still have me' referring to the fact he didn't blow himself up after all

264.speaker: Gale
264.text: I wanted to... to thank you. I was sinking into a dark place, but you reminded me there is still light in the world, if I should care to look for it.

82.speaker: Gale
82.text: You... you may well have prevented me from doing something very rash in the near future. I count myself lucky to call you a friend.

260.speaker: Gale
260.text: Careful - I may just take you up on that.

12.speaker: Player
12.text: I just don't want to be collateral damage.

332.speaker: Gale
332.text: Understandable. And you won't be. Not if I can help it.

344.speaker: Gale
344.text: I'm glad to hear it. And I intend to prove myself worthy of the sentiment.

199.speaker: Gale
199.text: I hope the city doesn't seem too small and quaint to you, now you've caught a glimpse of what lies above and beyond...

137.speaker: Gale
137.text: I had hoped to have a word with you about that, in fact. Our little voyage to the stars.

99.speaker: Player
99.text: A glimpse of eternity... I've thought of nothing else since.

119.speaker: Gale
119.text: What I proposed to you was something bolder than most mortals ever have to contend with, and yet your resolve was firm.

334.speaker: Gale
334.text: I wanted to see how you felt, on terra prima. Did our dream survive the waking from it?

10.speaker: Player
10.text: I said I'd support you, and I meant it.

320.speaker: Gale
320.text: Then my sore arms thank you - I can finally stop pinching myself.

321.speaker: Gale
321.text: I can't tell you how glad I am not to face such an undertaking alone. We will succeed where Karsus failed, I'm sure of it.

28.speaker: Gale
28.text: Standing side-by-side, even against such intimidating odds - how could we not?

108.speaker: Player
108.text: Are you questioning my feelings, or your own?

218.speaker: Gale
218.text: You know me too well. I'm second-guessing things, as usual.

254.speaker: Gale
254.text: That's the trouble with being quite clever - you always have to be right. Probe all avenues, consider all possibilities.

1.speaker: Gale
1.text: When I indulge impulsivity... as you know, the results can be quite catastrophic. But any path we walk together is the right one. I'm sure of that.

103.speaker: Gale
103.text: Was there anything else you wished to discuss?

259.speaker: Player
259.text: Perhaps... perhaps I was caught up in the moment.

35.speaker: Gale
35.text: I see. Then we should rest the topic for now, then. Perhaps the dream will yet prove true... or I will have to wake and face reality.

68.speaker: Gale
68.text: Thank you, for your candour, and your company. That night was still... very special for me.

161.speaker: Player
161.text: Don't tell me... you're having regrets.

279.speaker: Gale
279.text: No, no. I've never been more sure of anything.

61.speaker: Player
61.text: Not just now, Gale. There's something else I wanted to speak to you about.

72.speaker: Gale
72.text: I see you're still lost for words about the whole thing. No matter - what can I do for you?

253.speaker: Gale
253.text: I wanted to talk to you about our night together...

112.speaker: Gale
112.text: Have you ever walked to the very edge of a great precipice, and shuddered at how easy it would be to step into the void?

114.speaker: Gale
114.text: Ever since Elminster told me of Mystra's... expectations of me, I have felt like I've been walking along such a cliff face, with a great drop to nothingness never out of my sight.

293.speaker: Gale
293.text: But you - you led me away from the edge.

39.speaker: Gale
39.text: Without your words, your touch... I fear I would have sought purpose and solace in that void. You reminded me what living can feel like.

363.speaker: Player
363.text: You flatter me. As I recall, you did all the hard work.

105.speaker: Gale
105.text: Well, generosity is always a noble virtue - whether it be in the streets, at the charity box, or betwixt the sheets.

48.speaker: Gale
48.text: We are all sensual vessels. Illusory magic lets us sail farther, and feel more deeply.

238.speaker: Gale
238.text: I hope the end is much farther away than I had suspected. I hope that night meant as much to you as it did to me. And I hope we will have more time together. Together... alone.

157.speaker: Player
157.text: It was wonderful. I hope there is more to come as well.

326.speaker: Gale
326.text: I'll see that there is - woe betide anyone who tries to stop me.

88.speaker: Gale
88.text: Well, fine is... fine. Nobody weeps because the weather is fine. No monarchs were overthrown because their ruling was fine. No artworks were burned because they were not masterpieces, but merely fine.

49.speaker: Player
49.text: Would you have rather I lied?

268.speaker: Gale
268.text: The dignified thing for me to say is 'No, of course not. Forthrightness before all', but honestly? Yes... I would have rather you lied.

164.speaker: Gale
164.text: I'm just a man. An imperfect one, with needs, wants, and flaws by the bushel. A fragile vessel in which to place potentially world-ending power.

180.speaker: Gale
180.text: Perhaps it would be better to not shake such a vessel.

2.speaker: Gale
2.text: Forgive me. These were already trying times before Elminster delivered his missive. Now, for me at least, they are potentially end times.

155.speaker: Player
155.text: I'm just teasing - it was wonderful, and I'd like it to continue.

301.speaker: Gale
301.text: Oh... well, I hope I didn't make too much of an ass of myself just now.

244.speaker: Gale
244.text: I'll see that there is indeed more to come - woe betide anyone who tries to stop me.

165.speaker: Player
165.text: I think it's best if we both consider that night a one-off.

206.speaker: Player
206.text: Stop fishing for compliments. We have work to do.

197.speaker: Gale
197.text: Yes... yes we do. And perhaps the sooner it's done, the better.

340.speaker: Player
340.text: You've stoked those fires too high. That night was a once-off affair.

104.speaker: Gale
104.text: I see. Well, at least it was a night to remember... for one of us. I'll trouble you no more on the matter.

183.speaker: Gale
183.text: Besides, given my propensity towards verbosity, it surely can't be a surprise that I have a practised tongue.

0.speaker: Player
0.text: I'm glad to hear you say it. Keep focused on that feeling - you'll need that resolve soon enough.

75.speaker: Gale
75.text: Indeed. I'll guard my resolve like a lit flame in a... well, in a gale.

323.speaker: Player
323.text: Funny, I could say the same about you. That night was magical in more ways than one.

195.speaker: Gale
195.text: I had been hoping you'd say that. To be an object of pity... I couldn't live with that.

215.speaker: Player
215.text: I know you mean well... but that's a lot of pressure to put on me. I can't be your crutch.

290.speaker: Gale
290.text: No crutch - I can stand tall now, thanks to you. You've renewed my taste for living. I will not be a burden to you.

27.speaker: Player
27.text: Whatever it takes to prevent you from blowing up.

46.speaker: Gale
46.text: Indeed, most practical of you... I can only hope you did not find it an unpleasant endeavour.

9.speaker: Player
9.text: Not just now - there's something else we need to speak about.

273.speaker: Gale
273.text: It's quite thrilling, to fight off such grim creatures as this region throws at us. Especially being at your side.

142.speaker: Gale
142.text: I once read a book that explained in some detail the effect a brush with danger has on one's desire for... other forms of stimulation.
142.context: NodeContext: Implying danger makes people horny

181.speaker: Gale
181.text: Have you ever read anything on that subject?
181.context: NodeContext: Indirect - asking if you're feeling the same adrenaline rush/attraction that he's feeling

79.speaker: Gale
79.text: Only that I find you quite irresistible. Even illuminated by such rotten light as this place produces.

212.speaker: Gale
212.text: Perhaps it's just the thrill of our near-undead experience talking. But standing at your side through such darkness and disrepair, it only makes me want you more.

248.speaker: Gale
248.text: Unfortunately this is neither the time nor place to indulge such feelings. So, we must be patient and push all such thoughts aside. For now.

202.speaker: Gale
202.text: Was there anything else you wished to discuss?

65.speaker: Player
65.text: Read it? I could have written the thing.

125.speaker: Gale
125.text: I believe you. You never look so beautiful as at the end of a stirring battle, your cheeks flushed, gaze bright, muscles glistening...

47.speaker: Player
47.text: You're drawn to me, even in a place like this?

160.speaker: Gale
160.text: I can't imagine anywhere that could turn my heart from you, cursed or otherwise. You'd always be as beautiful, and as impressive.

98.speaker: Player
98.text: I'm not much of a reader. But I've seen some very informative diagrams...

311.speaker: Gale
311.text: You have? Then I might suggest we pool our knowledge. No sense in letting valuable first-hand experience go to waste, after all.

138.speaker: Player
138.text: Actually, there's a more interesting subject I want to discuss.

214.speaker: Gale
214.text: Of course. Such distractions are hardly the most important thing to discuss at present.

365.speaker: Gale
365.text: My love. I hope you enjoyed our voyage through the cosmos? I was hoping you might have a moment to talk about it...
365.context: NodeContext: Warm, loving greeting. Slightly nervous - he's going to bring up a subject he's worried about

182.speaker: Player
182.text: You showed me eternity. I haven't stopped thinking about it.

205.speaker: Gale
205.text: Neither have I - the closest thing to a deserving canvas on which to place your beauty. But I've also not forgotten why I took you there.
205.context: NodeContext: At first, dreamy and in love. Then getting to the point - Gale is worried his ambition has soured the relationship

232.speaker: Gale
232.text: I hope you don't think less of me. Great ambition should not come at the expense of what you already hold dear. I see that now.

85.speaker: Player
85.text: You listened to me. You understood my concerns. How could I think less of you for that?

78.speaker: Gale
78.text: What divine calculus plucked each of us from the ether, and thrust us together?
78.context: NodeContext: Appreciative and quietly awed by the player's support

140.speaker: Gale
140.text: I don't deserve you, truly. But I will do my utmost to earn the right.

266.speaker: Player
266.text: Good. Because I won't follow blind ambition. It leads nowhere.

151.speaker: Gale
151.text: I suppose I invited that caution I hear in your voice. And I will do my best to ease any lingering misgivings.

198.speaker: Gale
198.text: The highest ambition I harbour now is to see you smile, always.

21.speaker: Player
21.text: I've no wish to stifle your dreams. But pursuing the crown is a nightmare waiting to happen.

302.speaker: Gale
302.text: True. Perhaps my notions leaned too optimistic. I would not wish Karsus' past to become my future. Not while I have you.
